messages: 556aa3804812dec78f9e66179074e8de (02:00): i booted from the DVD, when it presented me the grub prompt, i replaced the proposed lines with the lines in the menu.lst file
556aa3804812dec78f9e66179074e8de (02:00): then i logged into the failsafe console and issued the "installgrub" command
556aa3804812dec78f9e66179074e8de (02:01): thanks  a lot for your help
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:01): nice
6b88ad0c0d868f527e66c1b8fcde89a3 (02:01): phalenor: seems not to work, i'll create a class-C network for the install
556aa3804812dec78f9e66179074e8de (02:02): is amazing how this community is willing to help everyone, normally in the linux channels i always get the usual RTFM
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (02:02): yarihm: out of interest, what are you jumpstarting from?
6b88ad0c0d868f527e66c1b8fcde89a3 (02:03): richlowe: i'm not jumpstarting ... i'm trying to do a network install of snv_42 onto a E3000 from a linux-machine ...
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:03): juanca: the solaris community can be just as bad at times
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:03): as always, there are good people and bad people
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:03): (#opensolaris is better than most Solaris-specific channels though)
556aa3804812dec78f9e66179074e8de (02:03): lol, in that case i have stumble on the good one, :)
6b88ad0c0d868f527e66c1b8fcde89a3 (02:04): phalenor: thanks for the hint BTW, i would not have figured out that it is because i'm not using a Class C network for the install
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:05): sun update manager does requires a fqdn that can be resolved instead of one a local network?
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (02:08): yarihm: I've had similar issues attempting to do it from a linux machine, I ended up giving in.
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (02:08): not exactly motivational, but, well, maybe helpful :)
6b88ad0c0d868f527e66c1b8fcde89a3 (02:12): richlowe: no problems using a solaris-server to install from?
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:19): hey, jm
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (02:21): hi one-n-all
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (02:25): hi sickness
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (02:25): so, what's new and super-groovy this morning?
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:26): we're moving to a colo that isn't absolutely shitty
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:26): (and leaving wikipedia behind)
a46678eb2f84e96084de2f2c30ecba9e (02:27): river_: what does "leave wikipedia behind" mean?
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:27): dprice: they're staying in the shitty colo
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (02:27): at the old colo, I'd assume.
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:27): (we buy internet access from wikimedia at the moment)
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (02:27): river_: I'd thought you guys were all different sides of the same thing.
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:27): no, separate organisations
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:27): wikimedia is 501(c)3 and wikia is profit-making
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (02:28): Oh, just regulatory split? that makes sense.
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:28): it's not really like that
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:28): jwales is on the board of both, but he runs them as separate entities
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:28): we don't profit from wikipedia, apart from the popularising wikis thing
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (02:29): !summon kupfer
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:29): it is kind of funny for a non-profit to sell net access to a company though..
f93451e33b8d6210b5adf42d5075df97 (02:29): can it wait until I finish lunch?
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (02:29): kupfer: Ok
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (02:29): river_: that's what I meant, I hadn't considered the profit v. not-profit thing. :)
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:30): rich: i'm just kind of sensitive about that because of the Bomis thing :)
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:30): (our colo was originally owned by bomis, an adult content company that jwales was involved with)
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:30): (so people like to claim that WP is funded by porn)
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (02:30): but *everything* is funded by porn these days
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (02:30): sounds like a good stiff strategy to me!
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:31): heh
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:31): well bomis wasn't even porn
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:31): that's the thing, it wasn't the kind of thing people make it out to be
556aa3804812dec78f9e66179074e8de (02:31): by the way can i read/mount ext3 partitions ?
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:32): http://www.bomis.com/
2ff36a90ba1881a7c4e8c481a35d00d3 (02:33): well, wikipedia is successful, so people will bash it  ;-)
2ff36a90ba1881a7c4e8c481a35d00d3 (02:33): call it... corpus envy
2ff36a90ba1881a7c4e8c481a35d00d3 (02:33): so, wikia is a competitor of say, socialtext ?
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:33): Furnace: not really
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:33): we are working with socialtext right now, actually
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:34): but there are lots of other free wiki hosts we complete with
2ff36a90ba1881a7c4e8c481a35d00d3 (02:34): so you do the hosting part?
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:34): we try to do both hosting and community
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:34): as opposed to other wiki hosts which just give you a wiki
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:35): hmm, i didn't even read that
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:35): i try to stay away from the politics of it all :)
2ff36a90ba1881a7c4e8c481a35d00d3 (02:36): so.. back to topic.. u use Solaris there?
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:36): no, Fedora
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:36): i'd like to use Solaris, but sadly it's not soley my choice
d29f7858616789349f2e17f17eaa3395 (02:37): openbsd and opensolaris
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:37): wikimedia is 99.9% Fedora too
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:37): which is kind of funny, because everyone hates it
2ff36a90ba1881a7c4e8c481a35d00d3 (02:37): I love Gentoo Linux, but for mission critical stuff I'm evaluating Solaris
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:37): it's not even suitable for wikimedia as a linux distribution
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:37): we'd do better on debian or rhel..
8b50238204c4fd2047bee47405ee3376 (02:38): We run quite a lot of mission critical on Gentoo.
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:38): what i hate about fedora is the same thing i like about solaris
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:38): you install a fedora box, and three months later they've EOL'd it
2ff36a90ba1881a7c4e8c481a35d00d3 (02:38): hehe ... hence Ubuntu LTS ?
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:38): but our solitary solaris box (running 3/05) has years left on its support life
2ff36a90ba1881a7c4e8c481a35d00d3 (02:38): yes, it's famous for that.
2ff36a90ba1881a7c4e8c481a35d00d3 (02:39): also maintaining compatibility, which most distros are not good at
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:39): yep
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:39): but somehow i can't get people to understand how this is bad
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:39): we had a box running RedHat 9 until last month

2ff36a90ba1881a7c4e8c481a35d00d3 (02:39): like, I fired up Solaris 10 for the first time, and I started bitching about how the default shell was csh, and so on... and a more experiened sysadmin reminded me, "That's ON PURPOSE..."
d151ca693f617f47c68797c351f1495e (02:39): watch out - Solaris 2.6 hits end of support this month, only 9 years after it originally shipped
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:40): and in the linux world, that's fairly old, but i think RH9 was out about the same time as Solaris 8/9
2ff36a90ba1881a7c4e8c481a35d00d3 (02:40): when was the last time you filed a ticket on it ? :-)
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (02:40): which is still fully supported
